newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnia's post-war parliament approves cabinet.
newsitem.headline: Bosnia's post-war parliament approves cabinet.

text.p: Bosnia's inter-ethnic parliament appointed a peacetime cabinet on Friday at its first full session, approving nominations for the ministries which make up the country's weak central government.
The Council of Ministers proposed by Bosnia's collective presidency was unopposed by the 42-member House of Representatives, elected in national polls in September, with only one deputy abstaining.
The Council of Ministers, or cabinet, is led by two co-chairmen, Haris Silajdzic, a Moslem and former Bosnian prime minister, and Boro Bosic, a Serb.
Jadranko Prlic, a Croat who served for a time as Bosnia's foreign minister, kept his post in the new cabinet.
Another Moslem, former premier Hasan Muratovic, was named as minister of foreign trade and a Serb, Spasoje Albijanic, will serve as minister of communications.
Each minister has two deputies and the posts are distributed equally among the three national communities.
The council, which will primarily handle issues touching on foreign relations, serves as a weak central authority ruling over Bosnia's autonomous Serb and Moslem-Croat territories.

Earlier, former enemies sat uncomfortably across an aisle and listened to speeches from all three members of the collective presidency in a museum room formerly reserved for aquariums and snakes in natural history exhibits.
"Now the real work must start," Michael Steiner, deputy to the international High Representative to Bosnia, told the deputies in a speech.
Bosnian voters "expect you to get the country back on track. They expect you to provide them with peaceful, decent living conditons," the German diplomat said.

The Moslem chairman of the presidency, Alija izetbegovic, wished the parliament success and called for the deputies to fully implement the Dayton peace accords which ended the 3-1/2 year war in November 1995.
The Serb member of the presidency, Momcilo Krajisnik, was greeted with an awkard silence from Moslem and Croat deputies when he rose to deliver his address.
His speech appeared to cast doubt on Bosnia's unity, as prescribed by Dayton.

Krajisnik, who bitterly opposed Bosnia's break from old Yugoslavia, said the former warring factions had agreed to recognise Bosnia's Moslem-Croat and Serb territories as "two states" but also said that Bosnia-Herzegovina "exists too".
Saying it was time to heal the wounds of war, Krajisnik warned that the peace would hold only if all three national communities had equal rights.
"Bosnia-Herzegovina can survive if we work hard to ensure all three nations and both entities feel equal and secure."
Serb deputies had boycotted an inaugural session of parliament in October, snubbing foreign dignitaries who had flown in for the ceremony.
The Serbs had cited objections to the venue in the city centre and to the text of an oath pledging loyalty to Bosnia as a single state.
Since then all the Serb deputies have signed the "solemn declaration" to the Bosnian constitution but avoided taking the oath in a public ceremony, diplomats said.
A 15-member upper chamber, the House of Peoples, is also due to convene for the first time in the Sarajevo suburb of Lukavica in Serb-controlled territory later on Friday.
